pros: The work is interesting, but there is almost no one left with experience.
cons:
I worked at the Conference Board for a number of years. It used to be a great place. However, a new president and ET team resulted in senior staff fleeing after they were treated badly. In one case, an entire team quit on the same day which I have never seen in an organization. Despite that, no one on the leadership team questioned why. Over about a year, almost every research director or senior staff has moved on. 
As mentioned in many other reviews, the new ET are not experts in the work they oversee. They are unable to speak to clients or provide any oversite on the work. The result is people with no experience are left to complete complicated projects with no input. 
This has had a terrible impact on the Board’s reputation. In some cases, we just couldn’t deliver on previous commitments. I have heard from many clients who were not happy with the quality of the work. While the finances have taken a hit, the board sold its building to cut back on expenses. Hopefully that buys them enough time to make changes and turn things around. It would be a shame to lose this historic organization. It is beyond time for the Board of Directors to step in and try and right this ship.
If you are thinking of joining this organization, I would read all the reviews here and speak to any of the 150 ex-employees who fled in the last two years.

pros: There are some very smart and dedicated people here. Middle-management leadership is decent and they try to make the best of fluctuating expectations and circumstances presented to them and their teams. There are talented researchers and economists who try to adjust accordingly.
cons:
Employee experiences differ a great deal at the organization. Experiences can range from feeling generally supported to undermined and abandoned by top leadership.

There is a persistent boys' club mentality at the organization that is not exclusive to the executive. It is prevalent in pockets across the organization and is not discouraged or frowned-upon.

A great deal of pressure is placed on very inexperienced or new staff. This is the result of extremely high turnover, recruitment and retainment issues and a general lack of resources. 

Stress related leaves and burnouts are common at every level. This further perpetuates the burnout issue for those who "pick up the work" when their colleagues leave or while they recover.

It is not a psychologically safe work environment. There is no formal structure in place to raise personal or work-related issues in a way that doesn't jeopardize your job. 

Inclusion and Diversity at the organization is surface deep. Staff are told that it matters to the organization, but leadership isn't fully on board and are unwilling to do much to support it.

Staff are leaving in droves (by choice). This applies to new hires of less than 6 months to long standing employees.

Reviews, such as this one, are discouraged for obvious reasons. Current staff who've posted previous reviews have been asked by leadership to delete their comments. Others have been fired.

The purpose of this review is for those considering a role at the organization. These are not bitter comments from a person who was fired. They're honest comments from a person who left.

pros: Nice colleagues, good work life balance, opportunities to learn and try new things and pay can be decent depending on your role.
cons:
Bullying is welcome at the Conference Board of Canada and it regrettably starts at the top of the organization. Numerous members of the Executive Team have been the subject of bullying complaints in recent months and while each one of them remain in their roles, most complainants have been ushered out the door under the guise of cost-cutting, obsolete skills, or the complainant having an attitude problem.

You would think that our new President's HR background would serve the organization well but she has weaponized her experience to shape the organization to her liking. Those that adopt a "win at all costs" mentality are getting ahead under her while genuinely good people are ushered out the door. 

Bullying has been commonplace at the Conference Board for years and while the organization has often been late to respond, it has in the recent past removed culprits. Under the new regime, this is yet to happen despite egregious cases of a VP, C-suite staff, a director and an associate director running riot knowing full well the President has their backing. 

In one particularly egregious case, an employee complained about their VP's behaviour and then weeks later that same VP sent out an email informing us that employee had been terminated. What message does that send?

Perhaps it will take another "APTN News" scandal to shock the Conference Board for appropriate action to be taken. For now, the bullying continues and there is no recourse for staff.

review_title: Great work life balance and Employee Engagement
pros: The Conference Board has been fully remote since March 13th when COVID measures were put in place. Our employee engagement and productivity levels have been great, maybe even better than when in the building so CBoC has decided to put the building up for sale and become a fully remote work environment. This is great for work life balance. The employees are putting in extra effort to connect and empower each other. The executive team has implemented several working groups to look at all areas of becoming remote and are committed to making it a good experience for all staff. The management team has really come together and seems to have weeded out all of the earlier issues from our organizational re-brand last year. I highly recommend working at the Conference Board.
cons: Due to COVID-19 there are some temporary lay offs and spending measures that had to be done. I’m sure when we come out of this all will go back to normal and measures will be undone.

pros: You get to work with very intelligent, outgoing people. The atmosphere is one where people don't hoard information, they share it with each other. The pay is good (at least, for economists) and there is a flexible work environment (working from home or on odd schedules, etc). The opportunity is amazing for people just coming out of school, as you get to publish papers and conduct media interviews, etc. There is a lot of exposure.
cons: Because it is a smaller organization (less than 200 people), there are not many opportunities for advancement. Expectations are high and people are often let go if they can't keep up with the workload and wining contracts. Compared to government and other organizations in the city, the benefits aren't great - especially the lack of parental benefits.

pros: In theory, there's annual bonus pay (unfortunately, this never materializes in practice).
cons: Ever since a few years ago, the Conference Board of Canada's mission and not-for-profit status has become a bit of a running joke. If there is one thing that is patently obvious while working here, it is that everything employees do, and are judged on, is about the margin, the bottom line, and profit. Nothing wrong with being for-profit, but there is an undeniable hypocrisy about a place that values appearance over substance and sleek websites over sound research . Case in point, the ever-increasing overhead and numbers of management at the expense of talented researchers who can actually do the work. Perhaps this is a good place to work as an administrative assistant or director, that I cannot say. But if you are a researcher, you have been warned.

pros: I have been a part of the Conference Board for a long time and reading the posts here breaks my heart. This is a great organization with great people, many of whom I am proud to call dear friends. I admit though we have been directionless and really struggled. We haven’t even made basic financial results in 5 years. This has impacted me financially as I used to depend on the annual bonus. There has been lots of staff turnover and that’s been hard but it was time for many of them to go.  So many people were being paid high salaries to do the bare minimum while a committed group worked double time for years to carry them. Some of these people were also were the loudest, most negative voices at the table and so entitled. This changeover was needed but I guess we need more. I don’t understand the animosity toward the new leadership. It feels like we finally have a President who cares about returning the Board to its former stature and I will speak up to say the things I see coming from the marketing department are a breath of fresh air and I hope they keep going.  I feel for my new and old colleagues in that department as the posts here do not show who the Board really is and can be. What they show is that there are still people kicking around who are spending time spreading negative energy instead of working with the rest of us to put things on track. Things are changing for sure and if you don’t like the changes, the Board is probably not the right place for you anymore but please, please don’t ruin it for the rest of us who are excited to be a part of it.
cons: Silos and remaining entitled people
